{{Orphan|date=August 2016}} {{Infobox person | image = | signature = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1965|5|16}} | occupation = President of the Management Board of Wratislavia Biodiesel S.A.
President of the Management Board of Akwawit-Polmos S.A.
President of the Management Board of Bartimpex S.A. }} '''Grzegorz Andrzej Ślak''' (born 16 May 1965 in [[:pl:Ostrzeszów|Ostrzeszów]]) - Polish entrepreneur, lawyer (specializing in excise duties), financier. == Career == Ślak started his career at [[:pl:Bank BPH|Bank Przemysłowo-Handlowy]] in [[Rybnik]], where he was involved mainly in financing and restructuring energy, steel and mining-related companies. In 2002 he became the President of the Management Board of [[:pl:Rafineria Trzebinia|Rafineria Trzebinia]]. As the first person in Poland, he has "built" a facility for producing higher fatty acid methyl esters ('biofuels') and pharmaceutical glycerine, thus becoming "the pioneer of Polish biofuels".{{Fact|date=August 2016}} In 2005, he "built" the first plant for hydrorefining of purified paraffin in Central and Eastern Europe under license by Exxon Mobil. The plant allowed for use of petroleum processing products (paraffin) in pharmaceutical, cosmetic and food industries.{{cite web|title=W Rafinerii Trzebinia pierwsza w Europie Środkowej instalacja hydrorafinacji parafin|url=http://www.pb.pl/1403402,89690,w-rafinerii-trzebinia-pierwsza-w-europie-srodkowej-instalacja-hydrorafinacji-parafin|accessdate=2015-08-28}} In 2005, he developed a new technology and started to produce a new fuel, trade name "ON BIO 10", consisting of diesel oil and 20% addition of higher fatty acid methyl esters. On this basis, the Minister of Economy adopted the quality standard for this fuel which is still in effect. For this product, Rafineria Trzebinia was awarded the Promotional Emblem “Teraz Polska” in 2006.{{cite web|title=Rafineria Trzebinia zaczęła sprzedawać ON BIO - prasa|url=http://www.pb.pl/1403029,19980,rafineria-trzebinia-zaczela-sprzedawac-on-bio-prasa|accessdate=2015-08-28}}{{cite web|title=ORLEN Południe|url=http://www.rafineria-trzebinia.pl/PL/OFirmie/Strony/Historia-Firmy.aspx|agency=www.rafineria-trzebinia.pl|accessdate=2015-08-28}}{{cite web|title=Biodiesel w sprzedaży|url=http://www.dziennikpolski24.pl/artykul/1559892,biodiesel-w-sprzedazy,id,t.html?cookie=1|accessdate=2015-08-28}} In June 2006, Ślak was accused of reducing the payable excise duties for the unprecedented amount of PLN 760 million in connection with his duties as the President of the Management Board of Rafineria Trzebinia. After two years, tax authorities confirmed accuracy of the settlements, thus accepting correctness of the tax rate applied by Ślak.{{cite web|title=Życie z prokuratorem na karku|url=http://www.newsweek.pl/grzegorz-slak-zaklada-fundacje-pomagajaca-ofiarom-prokuratury,artykuly,362347,1,z.html|accessdate=2015-08-28}} In 2006, he became the President of the Management Board of Skotan S.A., leading the company to one of its biggest stock increases on the Warsaw Stock Exchange.{{cite web|title=Skotan: nowy prezes zadba o biopaliwa|url=http://www.wnp.pl/wiadomosci/skotan-nowy-prezes-zadba-o-biopaliwa,11642.html|agency=wnp.pl|accessdate=2015-08-28}} In 2008, he became the President of the Management Board of Bioeton S.A. In this company, he carried out a capital investment which allowed for the takeover of BDK Kyritz GmbH, a German renewable energy company. In 2009, he became the President of the Management Board of BDK Kyritz GmbH in Germany. Ślak restructured the company, which involved restoring its financial liquidity. At that time, the company was in the state of so-called "temporary bankruptcy".{{cite web|title=Grzegorz Ślak pokieruje niemieckim producentem biopaliw|url=http://nafta.wnp.pl/grzegorz-slak-pokieruje-niemieckim-producentem-biopaliw,85746_1_0_0.html|agency=wnp.pl|accessdate=2015-08-28}} In July 2011 he took up the position of the President of the Management Board of Wratislavia Biodiesel S.A., a part of Bartimpex S.A capital group, which produces methyl esters and higher fatty acids (biodiesel), as well as raw and pharmaceutical glycerine. At the time of Ślak's taking up of the position, the company had not been operating due to a lack of contracts. As a result of his restructuring, Wratislavia Biodiesel S.A. generated a 7-digit net profit for the year 2012. At the same time, Ślak carried out an investment in bioethanol dehydrated spirit production plant, thus expanding the company's economic activity. The successful restructuring enabled the company to begin an application process for entering the stock market at the beginning of 2015.{{cite web|title=Mistrz paliw na prostej|url=http://www.forbes.pl/artykuly/sekcje/Strategie/mistrz-paliw-na-prostej,27789,1|accessdate=2015-08-28}}{{cite web|title=W imię Aleksandra|url=http://www.wprost.pl/ar/392188/W-imi-Aleksandra/|accessdate=2015-08-28}} As the President of the Management Board and a shareholder of Wratislavia Biodiesel S.A., he has been carrying out works to build a plant for producing algae fuels (third-generation fuels). If successful, it will be the first plant of this sort in Europe. Since October 2011, Ślak has been simultaneously holding the post of the President of the Management Board of Akwawit-Polmos S.A. (also a part of Bartimpex S.A capital group) - a producer of spirits and vodkas. At the time of Ślak's taking up of the position, the company had fulfilled all the legal requirements to file for bankruptcy.{{cite web|title=Grzegorz Ślak: Akwawit-Polmos liczy na nowy kontrakt|url=http://www.wnp.pl/wiadomosci/grzegorz-slak-akwawit-polmos-liczy-na-nowy-kontrakt,202217.html|agency=wnp.pl|accessdate=2015-08-28}} In 2012, his actions resulted in signing agreements with world-scale alcohol producers: one with Brown-Forman (the owner of Jack Daniels and Finlandia brands) for the production of Maximus vodka and another with Diageo (the owner of Johnnie Walker and Baileys) for the production of Smirnoff vodka. As a result of the financial restructuring, the company is planning to enter the stock market in 2016. As part of the restructuring process, Ślak carried out an investment in Poland's most modern alcohol production line licensed by CFT Packaging S.A. The line is able to produce 100 million bottles a year, which increases the overall productivity of Akwawit-Polmos S.A. to 150 million bottles a year, thus placing the company among the biggest alcohol producers in Central-Eastern Europe. In 2013, he replaced the deceased [[Aleksander Gudzowaty]] as the President of the Management Board of Bartimpex S.A.{{cite web|title=Grzegorz Ślak nowym prezesem spółki Bartimpex {{!}} Zmiany kadrowe {{!}} pulshr.pl|url=http://www.pulshr.pl/zmiany-kadrowe/grzegorz-slak-nowym-prezesem-spolki-bartimpex,13091.html|agency=www.pulshr.pl|accessdate=2015-08-28}} Ślak is the President of the Management Board and a shareholder of HGBS Finanse S.A, a fund investing in new technology and "excise business" enterprises. In his career, he has been or is a member of the following supervisory boards (among others): Orlen Oil S.A, J.W. Construction S.A., Orlen Asfalt S.A, Polonia Warszawa S.A., Euronaft Sp. z o.o. === Dispute over the offset agreement{{cite web|title=Wygrał z Lockheed Martin, ale liczy na więcej|url=http://www.forbes.pl/wygral-z-lockheed-martin-ale-liczy-na-wiecej,artykuly,183635,1,1.html|accessdate=2015-08-28}}{{cite web|title=Jak polski menedżer wyciągnął 13 mln dol. od amerykańskiego giganta|url=http://www.biztok.pl/biznes/jak-polski-menedzer-wyciagnal-13-mln-dol-od-amerykanskiego-giganta_s17823|last=Polska|first=Grupa Wirtualna|accessdate=2015-08-28}} === In April 2003, the Polish government signed an agreement with the U.S. for purchase of 48 F-16 jets for USD 3.5 million. In exchange, the Americans agreed, among others, to invest in Poland's economy and help Polish enterprises to invest in the American market. They failed to fulfill the latter point. In 2014, carrying out the duties of the President of Bartimpex Management Board, Grzegorz Ślak led the company to reach a settlement with Lockheed Martin under which the Polish company was awarded several million dollars in damages. Bartimpex was the only legal entity in Poland to have been awarded damages for the unfulfilled offset agreement conditions. === The Yamal–Europe gas pipeline{{cite web|title=PGNiG zapłaciło ponad 100 mln za przejęcie kontroli nad Jamałem|url=http://wiadomosci.radiozet.pl/Wiadomosci/Kraj/PGNiG-zaplacilo-ponad-100-mln-za-przejecie-kontroli-nad-Jamalem-00008522|last=ZET|first=Redakcja Radia|agency=PGNiG zapłaciło ponad 100 mln za przejęcie kontroli nad Jamałem - Wiadomości|accessdate=2015-08-28}}{{cite web|title=Spadkobiercy Gudzowatego oddali kontrolę nad gazem|url=http://www.pb.pl/4038128,41400,spadkobiercy-gudzowatego-oddali-kontrole-nad-gazem|accessdate=2015-08-28}} === Grzegorz Ślak initiated the PGNiG takeover of the part of the Yamal–Europe gas pipeline that goes through Poland. The transaction enabled PGNiG to take over 4% of the shares, which gave it advantage over Gazprom (52% to 48%) and guaranteed the Polish party the decisive vote on the most significant matters concerning EuropolGaz, the owner of the pipeline. == Awards == He was awarded the Silver Cross of Merit for ''contributions to the development of oil industry'' pursuant to the Polish President's Decree of 4 June 2003.{{cite web|title=Internetowy System Aktów Prawnych|url=http://isap.sejm.gov.pl/DetailsServlet?id=WMP20030480724|last=RP|first=Kancelaria Sejmu|agency=isap.sejm.gov.pl|accessdate=2015-08-28}} He received "Man of the year 2005" Medal awarded by ''Gazeta Krakowska'' for "professionalism in company management, introducing innovative technologies, effectiveness in winning new markets and supporting culture and sport".{{cite web|title=Grzegorz Ślak Człowiekiem Roku|url=http://www.neurochirurgia-tarnow.com.pl/download/g_krak22_str12.pdf|agency=Neurochirurgia Tarnów|accessdate=2015-09-09}} == Community involvement == He funded two ultrasound devices which allow for earlier cancer detection for the Department of Internal Medicine, Occupational Diseases and Occupational Hypertension of University Teaching Hospital in Wrocław.{{cite web|title=Lekarze uratowali mu mamę, więc kupił szpitalowi dwa aparaty USG|url=http://www.gazetawroclawska.pl/artykul/1012485,lekarze-uratowali-mu-mame-wiec-kupil-szpitalowi-dwa-aparaty-usg,id,t.html?cookie=1|accessdate=2015-08-28}} He funded a gamma camera used for an effective thyroid examination for the Department of Endocrinology in Zabrze.{{cite web|title=Zdrowie pod obserwacją - Będzin - naszemiasto.pl|url=http://bedzin.naszemiasto.pl/archiwum/zdrowie-pod-obserwacja,610334,art,t,id,tm.html|agency=bedzin.naszemiasto.pl|accessdate=2015-08-28}} He funded a device which facilitates performing cancer surgery in children for the Department of Pediatric Surgery and Urology of Wrocław Medical University. == Hobbies == Ślak is an avid enthusiast of football and motorcycle speedway. In 2004 and 2005, he led the speedway team Unia Tarnów to its first in history title of the winner of Team Speedway Polish Championship. For many years, he has been connected with Polish speedway rider Tomasz Gollob, who officially handed the 2010 gold medal for winning Individual Speedway World Championship over to Ślak. In 2010, he also wrote a book, entitled ''Why only now?! Gollob as the world champion. A true story''.{{cite web|title=Dlaczego dopiero teraz?! Gollob Mistrzem Świata. Historia prawdziwa - Grzegorz Ślak - Merlin.pl|url=http://merlin.pl/Dlaczego-dopiero-teraz-Gollob-Mistrzem-Swiata-Historia-prawdziwa_Whitered/browse/product/1,897358.html|agency=merlin.pl|accessdate=2015-08-28}} In 2008, he carried out a capital transaction which led to the takeover of Groclin Dyskobolia Grodzisk Wlkp. by the shareholder of J.W. As a result, the club changed its name to Polonia Warszawa and the registered seat to the city of Warsaw. It was the first transaction of this sort and so far one of a kind on the top level of Polish football events.{{cite web|title=Od 1 sierpnia Grzegorz Ślak prezesem Polonii|url=http://www.sport.pl/sport/1,78991,5463748,Od_1_sierpnia_Grzegorz_Slak_prezesem_Polonii.html|accessdate=2015-08-28}} He acts as a speedway expert and Grand Prix commentator on Canal+. ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Slak, Grzegorz}} [[Category:1965 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Polish businesspeople]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox television | show_name = High Flyers | image = High_Flyers_title_card.jpg | caption = Title card of ''High Flyers'' | image_size = 260px | rating = | creator = | presenter = [[Haslinda Amin]] | executive_producer = | country = Singapore | language = English | network = [[Bloomberg Television]] | picture_format = | location = [[Singapore Flyer]], Singapore | camera = [[Multi-camera]] | distributor = | num_series=4 | company = [[AsiaWorks]] | runtime = 30 minutes <small>({{tooltip|inc.|including}} adverts)</small> | first_aired = 2011 | last_aired = present | num_episodes = | website = https://www.bloomberg.com/video/high-flyers/3/ }}
'''''High Flyers''''' is a business-themed television interview program, hosted by Haslinda Amin, which airs in selected regions on [[Bloomberg Television]].
In each episode, Haslinda interviews prominent or senior business figures inside one of the passenger capsules of the [[Singapore Flyer]] [[Ferris wheel]] in [[Singapore]]. Multiple cameras, technical equipment and crew are present in the capsule as it completes a full revolution of the wheel during filming.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asiaworks.com/2014/03/20/2014320high-flyers/|title=High Flyers for Bloomberg|date=14 March 2014|accessdate=6 August 2015}}</ref>
The initial series was sponsored by [[Australia and New Zealand Bank|ANZ]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.onscreenasia.com/article/bloomberg-flies-high/8790|title=Bloomberg flies high|date=22 August 2011|accessdate=6 August 2015|work=On Screen Asia}}</ref>
==Broadcast== The series premiered in 2011 on Bloomberg Television's Asia Pacific feeds.<ref name="s1">{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2011-08-22/bloomberg-tv-presents-high-flyers-with-host-haslinda-amin|title=Bloomberg TV Presents “High Flyers” with Host Haslinda Amin|date=23 August 2011|accessdate=6 August 2015|work=Bloomberg}}</ref> An eight episode second season premiered in 2013, which also aired in Bloomberg's [[Europe, the Middle East and Africa|EMEA]] markets.<ref name="s2">{{cite web|url=http://www.onscreenasia.com/article/-high-flyers-returns-with-second-season-on-bloomberg-tv/12421|title=“High Flyers” returns with second season on Bloomberg TV|work=On Screen Asia|date=5 June 2013|accessdate=6 August 2015}}</ref> The third season premiered on 6 June 2014 and a fourth season of the program premiered on 23 July 2015.<ref name="s4">{{cite web|url=http://www.asiaworks.com/2015/05/01/quick-update-asiaworks-singapore/|title=A Quick Update from AsiaWorks Singapore |date=1 May 2015|work=AsiaWorks|accessdate=7 August 2015}}</ref>
==Guests== The following business leaders have been interviewed on ''High Flyers'':
===Season 1=== * [[Sandiaga Uno]], co-founder of Saratoga Capital<ref name="s1"/> * [[Tony Fernandes]], CEO of [[AirAsia]]<ref name="s1"/> * [[Ho Kwon Ping]], founder of [[Banyan Tree Holdings]]<ref name="s1"/>
===Season 2=== * [[Tony Fernandes]], Group Chief Executive Director of AirAsia<ref name="s2"/> * [[Jimmy Choo]], founder of the luxury shoemaker<ref name="s2"/> * [[Tetsuya Wakuda]], celebrity chef and restaurateur<ref name="s2"/> * [[Erick Thohir]], media mogul<ref name="s2"/> * [[Mokhzani Mahathir]], the Executive Vice-Chairman of Sapura Kencana<ref name="s2"/>
===Season 3=== * Malvinder Singh, [[Fortis Healthcare]]. Aired 6 June, 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/video/malvinder-singh-high-flyers-06-06-6PuxUZTySbSdAWyfRsDxxQ.html|title=Bloomberg Video: High Flyers|work=Bloomberg|accessdate=20 August 2015}}</ref><ref>https://twitter.com/haslindatv/status/475138404984688641</ref> * Noni Purnomo, [[BlueBird Group]]. Aired 13 June, 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/video/blue-bird-s-noni-purnomo-high-flyers-06-13-WJeXpCbZRlmHyyfOOIkb2Q.html|title=Bloomberg Video: High Flyers|work=Bloomberg|accessdate=20 August 2015}}</ref> * [[Justin Quek]], celebrity chef. Aired 20 June, 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/video/celebrity-chef-justin-quek-high-flyers-06-20-Q9eX5QsNRYGIaotp5PVSuQ.html|title=Bloomberg Video: High Flyers|work=Bloomberg|accessdate=20 August 2015}}</ref> * Thomas Flohr, founder of [[VistaJet]]. Aired 27 June, 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/video/vistajet-s-thomas-flohr-high-flyers-06-27-koj_BKKLQ868R32M8pZWHQ.html|title=Bloomberg Video: High Flyers|work=Bloomberg|accessdate=20 August 2015}}</ref> * Sudhitham Chirathivat. Aired 11 July, 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/video/sudhitham-chirathivat-high-flyers-07-11-EmoU7J7YRsm5xj2GJc_cZg.html|title=Bloomberg Video: High Flyers|work=Bloomberg|accessdate=20 August 2015}}</ref> * Peter Bond, CEO of Link Energy. Aired 18 July, 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/video/linc-energy-s-peter-bond-high-flyers-07-18-otMX43A7TumH1PWJ3ghHhg.html|title=Bloomberg Video: High Flyers|work=Bloomberg|accessdate=20 August 2015}}</ref> * [[Ashley Isham]], fashion designer. Aired 24 July, 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/video/fashion-designer-ashley-isham-high-flyers-07-24-P7~~T5TtSfSR4YALYrY1RA.html|title=Bloomberg Video: High Flyers|work=Bloomberg|accessdate=20 August 2015}}</ref> * [[Hiroshi Mikitani]], CEO of [[Rakuten]]. Aired 31 July, 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/video/rakuten-s-hiroshi-mikitani-high-flyers-07-31-Cjl2~MBfRHygEa45zgJiow.html|title=Bloomberg Video: High Flyers|work=Bloomberg|accessdate=20 August 2015}}</ref> * Alain Li, CEO of [[Richemont]]. Aired 7 August, 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/video/richemont-s-alain-li-high-flyers-08-07-4NIX5I0BTW~wtTjVnnNtrQ.html|title=Bloomberg Video: High Flyers|work=Bloomberg|accessdate=20 August 2015}}</ref> * [[Hary Tanoesoedibjo]], CEO of [[MNC Group]]. Aired 14 August, 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/video/hary-tanoesoedibjo-high-flyers-08-14-ftAPlCxvR36wK3rM_IFlvQ.html|title=Bloomberg Video: High Flyers|work=Bloomberg|accessdate=20 August 2015}}</ref> * Ken Dean Lawadinata. Aired 21 August, 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/video/ken-dean-lawadinata-high-flyers-08-21-XeHJaiPuTwaf8ALcdvIA~A.html|title=Bloomberg Video: High Flyers|work=Bloomberg|accessdate=20 August 2015}}</ref> * [[Merrill Fernando]] and [[Dilhan Fernando]], founders of [[Dilmah]]. Aired 28 August, 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/video/dilmah-tea-s-merrill-dilhan-fernando-high-flyers-08-28-5ubLgSNjTvqAiXCFvtQBCA.html|title=Bloomberg Video: High Flyers|work=Bloomberg|accessdate=20 August 2015}}</ref>
===Season 4=== * [[Ruslan Kogan]], founder of [[Kogan.com]]. Aired 24 July, 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/videos/2015-07-24/kogan-com-s-ruslan-kogan-we-want-tech-savvy-people|title=Kogan.com's Ruslan Kogan: We Want Tech-Savvy People|work=Bloomberg|date=24 July 2015|accessdate=7 August 2015}}</ref> * Rosaline Koo, founder of ConnecXionsAsia (CXA). Aired 30 July, 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/videos/2015-08-13/cxa-s-rosaline-koo-high-flyers-full-show-7-30-\ |title=CXA's Rosaline Koo: High Flyers (Full Show 7/30)|work=Bloomberg|date=13 August 2015|accessdate=19 August 2015}}</ref> * Anthony Tan, founder of [[GrabTaxi]]. Aired 6 August 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/tv/schedule/asia/ |title=Asia-Pacific TV Schedule - Week beginning August 3 2015 |work=Bloomberg Television |accessdate=7 August 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150806231147/http://www.bloomberg.com/tv/schedule/asia/ |archivedate=August 6, 2015 }}</ref> * Apichart Chutrakul, developer in [[Thailand]]. Aired 13 August 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/videos/2015-08-17/apichart-chutrakul-high-flyers-full-show-8-13-|title=Apichart Chutrakul: High Flyers (Full Show 8/13)|work=Bloomberg|date=18 August 2015|accessdate=19 August 2015}}</ref> * [[Kiran Mazumdar-Shaw]], founder of [[Biocon]]. Aired 20 August 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/videos/2015-08-20/inside-the-dna-of-india-s-biocon|title=Inside the DNA of India's Biocon - Bloomberg Business|work=Bloomberg|date=20 August 2015|accessdate=20 August 2015}}</ref> * Harald and Caroline Link, founding family of B. Grimm. Aired 27 August 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/videos/2015-08-27/harald-and-caroline-link-what-it-means-to-be-thai|title=Harald and Caroline Link: What It Means to Be Thai|work=Bloomberg|date=28 August 2015|accessdate=28 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/tv/schedule/asia/ |title=Asia-Pacific TV Schedule - Week beginning August 24 2015 |work=Bloomberg Television |accessdate=28 August 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150828043155/http://www.bloomberg.com/tv/schedule/asia/ |archivedate=August 28, 2015 }}</ref> * [[Dato Sri Tahir]], founder of [[Mayapada Group]] in Indonesia. Aired 3 September 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/videos/2015-09-03/mayapada-group-s-tahir-high-flyers-full-show-9-03-|title=Mayapada Group's Tahir: High Flyers (Full Show 9/03)|work=Bloomberg|date=4 September 2015|accessdate=11 September 2015}}</ref> * Henry Nguyen, CEO of Vietnam's first venture capital fund. Aired 10 September 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/videos/2015-09-11/idg-ventures-henry-nguyen-high-flyers-full-show-9-10-|title=IDG Ventures' Henry Nguyen: High Flyers (Full Show 9/10)|work=Bloomberg|date=11 September 2015|accessdate=11 September 2015}}</ref> * [[Ruben Gnanalingam]], CEO of Westports. Aired 17 September 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/videos/2015-09-17/westports-ruben-gnanalingam-family-is-my-top-priority|title=Westports' Ruben Gnanalingam: Family Is My Top Priority|date=17 September 2015|accessdate=25 September 2015}}</ref> * [[Serge Pun]] and Melvyn Pun, Myanmar business family. Aired 24 September 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/videos/2015-09-25/serge-and-melvyn-pun-a-myanmar-success-story|title=Serge and Melvyn Pun: A Myanmar Success Story|work=Bloomberg|date=25 September 2015|accessdate=25 September 2015}}</ref> * [[David Thompson (chef)|David Thompson]], Australian chef. Aired 1 October 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/videos/2015-10-02/meet-celebrity-chef-and-restaurateur-david-thompson|title=Meet Celebrity Chef and Restaurateur David Thompson|work=Bloomberg|date=1 October 2015|accessdate=6 October 2015}}</ref> * The Mouawad Family, family of jewelers. Aired 8 October 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/videos/2015-10-09/the-mouawad-family-s-enduring-love-for-jewelry|title=The Mouawad Family's Enduring Love for Jewelry|work=Bloomberg|date=9 October 2015|accessdate=9 October 2015}}</ref>
===Season 5=== * [[Arun Pudur]], founder - CEO of Celframe. Aired 7th July 2016 <ref name="High Flyers">{{cite web |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/videos/2016-07-08/arun-pudur-on-high-flyers-07-07 |title=Full Show: Arun Pudur on ''High Flyers'' |date=2016-07-08 |accessdate=2016-07-26 |publisher=Bloomberg Television}}</ref>
==Technical== The production has filmed the series using the Sony EX-3 camera, [[Canon C300]] and [[GoPro]]s.<ref name="s4"/>
==Awards== {| class="wikitable collapsible" |- style="text-align:center;" ! colspan=5 style="background:#B0C4DE;" | List of accolades |- style="text-align:center;" ! style="background:#ccc;" width="10%"| Year ! style="background:#ccc;" width="20%"| Award ! style="background:#ccc;" width="30%"| Category ! style="background:#ccc;" width="20%"| Recipient(s) ! style="background:#ccc;" width="20%"| Result |- style="border-top:2px solid gray;" |- |rowspan="1"| 2014 |rowspan="1"| [[Asian Television Awards]] |Best Talk Show<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.onscreenasia.com/article/19th-asian-television-awards-nominees-unveiled/16146|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141115235533/http://ata.onscreenasia.com/ata2014/nomination-list.asp|title=Asian Television Awards 2014 Nominations List|work=Asian Television Awards|accessdate=7 August 2015|archivedate=15 November 2014}}</ref> |''High Flyers'' |{{nom}} |}

revision.text:
{{More citations needed|date=September 2014}} The '''Hilton family''' is an [[United States|American]] family. The family members hold varying degrees of wealth and status as [[socialite]]s in the [[United States|United States of America]]. They are widely known for the [[Hilton Hotels & Resorts]] Group which was established by [[Conrad Hilton]] in 1919 when he bought his first hotel.<ref>{{cite web|title=The history of Hilton hotels|url=http://www3.hilton.com/en/about/hilton/history/index.html|website=Hilton|accessdate=19 July 2017}}</ref>
== Family tree ==
* Halvor Nilsen Hilton (1810–1864), m. Karoline Hansdatter "Kari" Holum. :* Augustus Halvorson "Gus" Hilton b. Norway (1854–1919), m. Mary Genevieve Laufersweiler (1863–1956). :: Gus emigrated to the United States in 1870. ::* Felice A. Hilton (1885–1968) ::* [[Conrad Hilton]] (1887–1979) ::* Eva C. Hilton (1889–1979) ::* Carl H. Hilton (1892–1957) ::* Julian Hilton (1895–1897) ::* Rosemary J. Hilton (1898–1995) ::* August H. "Boy" Hilton (1901–1929) ::* Helen A. Hilton (January 30, 1906 – February 22, 2003)
===Conrad Hilton descendants=== * By first wife Mary Adelaide Barron (m. 1925, div. 1934) * [[Conrad Hilton Jr.|Conrad Nicholson "Nicky" Hilton Jr.]] (1926–1969), m. Patricia "Trish" McClintock. He was also the first husband of [[Elizabeth Taylor]]. ** Conrad Nicholson Hilton, III (b. 1960) ** Michael Otis Hilton (b. 1961), m. Babita Hilton. ::* Michael Bradford Hilton (b.1994) ::* Grant Hilton (b. 1995) ::* Isabelle Hilton (b. 2008)
* [[Barron Hilton|William Barron Hilton]] (b. 1927), m. Marilyn Hawley. :* William Barron Hilton, Jr. (b. 1948) :* Hawley Anne Hilton (b. 1949, m. Jack McAuliffe :** [[Justin McAuliffe|Justin Hawley McAuliffe]] (b. 1987) :* [[Steven M. Hilton|Steven Michael Hilton]] (b. 1950)<ref>http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-head-hilton-foundation-retires-20140324-story.html#axzz2xbvCVY7W</ref> ::* Nicholas Conrad Hilton (b. 1984) :* David Alan Hilton (b. 1952) :* Sharon Constance Hilton (b. 1953) :* [[Richard Hilton|Richard Howard Hilton]] (b. 1955), m. [[Kathy Hilton|Kathy Richards]] (half sister of [[Kim Richards|Kim]] and [[Kyle Richards]]) ::* [[Paris Hilton|Paris Whitney Hilton]] (b. 1981) ::* [[Nicky Hilton Rothschild|Nicholai Olivia Hilton]] (b. 1983), m. James Rothschild in 2015 ::**Lily-Grace Victoria Rothschild (b. 2016) ::**Teddy Marilyn Rothschild (b. 2017) ::* Barron Nicholas Hilton II (b. 1989), m. [[Tessa Gräfin von Walderdorff]] in 2017 ::* Conrad Hughes Hilton (b. 1994)
:* Daniel Kevin Hilton (b. 1962) :* Ronald Jeffrey Hilton (b. 1963) * [[Eric Hilton|Eric Michael Hilton]] (1932–2016)<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.chron.com/houston/article/Son-of-Hilton-founder-dies-10787973.php|title=Dallas-born son of Hilton founder dies|newspaper=Houston Chronicle|access-date=2016-12-10}}</ref> :* Eric Michael Hilton, Jr. (b. 1954) :* Beverly Ann Hilton (b. 1956) :* Linda Marie Hilton (b. 1963)m Fabrizio Buschini 1992 :** Nicholas Angelo Buschini (b. 1993) :** Brandon Alexandro Buschini (b. 1995) :* Joseph Bradley Hilton (b. 1967) :** Darren Joseph Hilton (b. 1995) :** Dean Bradley Hilton (b. 1995) :** Allison Elane Hilton (b. 2002) * By second wife [[Zsa Zsa Gabor]] (m. 1942, div. 1946) :* [[Francesca Hilton|Constance Francesca Gabor Hilton]]<ref>{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/SHOWBIZ/celebrity.news.gossip/04/14/gabor.baby/index.html?hpt=T2|title=Zsa Zsa Gabor to become new mother at 94, husband says|first=Alan|last=Duke|publisher=CNN|date=April 19, 2011}}</ref> (1947–2015)<ref>[http://www.aol.com/article/2015/01/06/francesca-hilton-daughter-of-zsa-zsa-gabor-dies-at-67/21125677/ Notice of death of Francesca Hilton], aol.com; accessed January 6, 2015.</ref> ::*Francesca was the only child born to any of the [[Gabor sisters]]. She had no children and was divorced. * No children by third wife Mary Frances Kelly (m. 1976).
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.wargs.com/other/hilton.html Ancestry of Paris Hilton]

[[Naushon Island]], [[Dukes County, Massachusetts]], U.S. | education = [[Phillips Academy]]
[[Round Hill School]] | alma mater = | occupation = Railroad magnate, merchant, financier | spouse = Sarah Hathaway | children = 6, including [[William Hathaway Forbes|William]], [[John Malcolm Forbes|John]] | relatives = [[Robert Bennet Forbes]] (brother)
[[Francis Blackwell Forbes|Francis B. Forbes]] (cousin)
[[John Murray Forbes (diplomat)|John Murray Forbes]] (uncle)
[[Thomas Handasyd Perkins|Thomas H. Perkins]] (uncle) }} '''John Murray Forbes''' (February 23, 1813 – October 12, 1898) was an American railroad [[magnate]], [[merchant]], philanthropist and [[Abolitionism in the United States|abolitionist]]. He was president of both the [[Michigan Central railroad]] and the [[Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad]] in the 1850s. He kept doing business with [[Russell & Company]]. ==Early life== Forbes was born on February 23, 1813, in [[Bordeaux]], France. His father, Ralph Bennett Forbes, was a member of the [[Forbes family]], descended from Scottish immigrants who attempted unsuccessfully to start a trade from Bordeaux. His mother, Margaret Perkins, was a member of the [[Boston Brahmin]] Perkins family merchant dynasty involved in the China trade. Among his siblings was older brother was [[Robert Bennet Forbes]], [[sea captain]] and [[Old China Trade|China]] [[merchant]].Smith, George Winston. "Broadsides for Freedom: Civil War Propaganda in New England." ''The New England Quarterly'', Vol. 21, No. 3. (Sep., 1948), pp. 291–312. His paternal uncle was [[John Murray Forbes (diplomat)|John Murray Forbes]], lawyer and [[diplomat]], and his maternal uncle was merchant [[Thomas Handasyd Perkins]]. Among his cousins was the botanist [[Francis Blackwell Forbes]]. In 1814, his parents moved back to the [[Captain Robert Bennet Forbes House]] in [[Milton, Massachusetts]]. Forbes attended school at [[Phillips Academy]] in [[Andover, Massachusetts]], then at [[Round Hill School]] in [[Northampton, Massachusetts]], from 1823 to 1828. ==Career== Forbes was one of three brothers sent by their uncle to [[Guangzhou|Canton, China]], and achieved some financial success during a short time spent trading in Canton. However, unlike his brother [[Robert Bennet Forbes|Robert]], who devoted himself to the China trade, Forbes returned to [[Boston]] and became an early railroad investor and landowner. As with [[Jay Gould]] and [[E. H. Harriman]], Forbes was an important figure in the building of America's railroad system. From March 28, 1846 through 1855, he was president of [[Michigan Central Railroad]], and he was a director and president of the [[Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad]], he helped with the growth of the American Middle West.Pearson, Henry. ''An American Railroad Builder: John Murray Forbes'', Houghton, Mifflin & Co., 1911. In addition, he founded [[J.M. Forbes & Co.]], an investment firm in Boston in 1838.{{cite web |url=http://www.jmforbes.com/history/ |title=History of J.M. Forbes & Co. |website=J.M. Forbes & Co. |access-date=October 17, 2015 }} In 1860, he was an elector for [[Abraham Lincoln]]. He served as the Chairman of the [[Republican National Committee]] during the administration of President [[Abraham Lincoln]]. Staunchly pro-Union, he is given credit for founding the New England [[Loyal Publication Society]] in early 1863 (Smith 1948). Historical Note: In 1863, John Murray Forbes, served as a 'confidential agent' of Secretary of the Navy, Gideon Wells, in Paris, France. Source: Office of Naval Records and Library, Record Group 45, indicating a 'gift of personal papers'. Citation: "The Union", A Guide to Federal Archives Relating to the Civil War, 1986, edited by K.W. Munden and H. P. Beers, 452. After the Civil War, Forbes was elected as a 3rd Class (honorary) Companion of the [[Military Order of the Loyal Legion of the United States]]. Forbes was a delegate to the Republican conventions of 1876, 1880 and 1884, he eventually became displeased with the Republican party and worked successfully to get Democrat [[Grover Cleveland]] elected President. ===Philanthropy=== He supplied money and weapons to New Englanders to fight slavery in [[Kansas]] and in 1859 entertained [[John Brown (abolitionist)|John Brown]]. Forbes's many philanthropic activities included the re-establishment of [[Milton Academy]], a preparatory school south of [[Boston, Massachusetts]] in 1884.Hughes (editor), Sarah Forbes.''Life and Recollections of John Murray Forbes'', Two Volumes, Houghton, Mifflin & Co., 1899. ==Personal life== Forbes married Sarah Swain Hathaway (1813–1900). They resided in Milton, Massachusetts, and summered on [[Naushon Island]] in [[Dukes County, Massachusetts]]. They had two sons and four daughters:{{cite web |title=Edith Emerson Forbes and William Hathaway Forbes Papers and Additions, 1827-1969 |url=https://www.masshist.org/collection-guides/view/fa0225 |website=www.masshist.org |publisher=[[Massachusetts Historical Society]] |accessdate=19 July 2018 |language=en}} * Ellen Randolph Forbes (1838–1860), who did not marry. * Alice Hathaway Forbes (1838–1917), who married Edward Montague Cary (1828–1888) in 1875. * [[William Hathaway Forbes]] (1840–1897), who married Edith Emerson (1841–1929), the daughter of poet [[Ralph Waldo Emerson]].{{cite news|title=William Hathaway Forbes |url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/80679284/?terms=%22William%2BHathaway%2BForbes%22 |newspaper=The Norfolk Virginian |location=Norfolk, Virginia |date=October 24, 1897 |page=10 |via = [[Newspapers.com]]|accessdate = October 12, 2015}} {{Open access}} William became the first president of the [[American Telephone and Telegraph Company]] and father of [[William Cameron Forbes]].Pier, Arthur. ''Forbes: Telephone Pioneer'', 1953. * Mary Hathaway Forbes (1844–1916), who married [[Henry S. Russell|Henry Sturgis Russell]] (1838–1905) in 1863. * [[John Malcolm Forbes]] (1847–1904), the [[yachtsman]] and [[Equestrianism|horseman]] who married Sarah Coffin Jones (1852–1891) in 1873. * Sarah Forbes (1853–1917), who married William Hastings Hughes (1833–1909) in 1887. Forbes died of [[pneumonia]] on October 12, 1898 in Milton, Massachusetts.{{cite news|title=John Murray Forbes Is Dead. Wealthy New Englander Passes Away At Milton, Mass. |url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/34196407/?terms=%22John%2BMurray%2BForbes%22 |newspaper=[[Chicago Inter Ocean]] |location=Chicago, Illinois |date=October 13, 1898 |page=5 |via = [[Newspapers.com]]|accessdate = October 12, 2015}} {{Open access}} ===Descendants=== His cousin [[Francis Blackwell Forbes]] (1839–1908) is the great-grandfather of 2004 U.S. [[United States Democratic Party|Democratic]] presidential candidate [[John Kerry|John Forbes Kerry]]. His 4x great-grandson is [[Jonathan Meath]], a renowned [[Emmy award|Emmy award-winning]] television producer.{{cite news|title=Mary Stewart Hewitt |publisher=''Monadnock Ledger-Transcript'' |quote=She is survived by her husband, Peter M. Hewitt; two daughters, Margaret F. Meath of Lorton, Va., and Sarah M. Tibbetts of Scituate, Mass.; two sons, James S. Huntington-Meath of Chapel Hill, N.C., and Jonathan G. Meath of Cambridge, Mass. |date=Jan 10, 2010 |url=http://www.ledgertranscript.com/article/mary-stewart-hewitt |accessdate=2010-11-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100221041515/http://www.ledgertranscript.com/article/mary-stewart-hewitt |archivedate=2010-02-21 |df= }} ===Legacy=== In the September 1899 issue of "''Atlantic''" magazine, [[Edward Waldo Emerson]] (Ralph Waldo Emerson's son), published Forbes' biography. The Emerson and Forbes families were close as Forbes' son, [[William Hathaway Forbes|William]], married Ralph's daughter, Edith Emerson. In ''Letters and Social Aims'', [[Ralph Waldo Emerson]] wrote of Forbes:
"Never was such force, good meaning, good sense, good action, combined with such domestic lovely behavior, such modesty and persistent preference for others. Wherever he moved he was the benefactor... How little this man suspects, with his sympathy for men and his respect for lettered and scientific people, that he is not likely, in any company, to meet a man superior to himself," and "I think this is a good country that can bear such a creature as he."{{White - America's most noteworthy railroaders}}
The small community of [[Forbes, Missouri]], is named for him.{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RfAuAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA174#v=onepage&q&f=false | title=How Missouri Counties, Towns and Streams Were Named | publisher=The State Historical Society of Missouri | author=Eaton, David Wolfe | year=1916 | pages=174}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://www.uua.org/uuhs/duub/articles/johnforbes.html Dictionary of Unitarian & Universalist Biography: John Murray Forbes] * ''[http://oprt.org/history-4.htm Old Plank Road Trail history and development]''. Retrieved October 2, 2013. * {{fg|167851795}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Forbes, John Murray}} [[Category:1813 births]] [[Category:1898 deaths]] [[Category:People from Bordeaux]] [[Category:People from Milton, Massachusetts]] [[Category:People from Dukes County, Massachusetts]] [[Category:Phillips Academy alumni]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Boston]] [[Category:19th-century American railroad executives]] [[Category:Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad people]] [[Category:Massachusetts Republicans]] [[Category:Massachusetts Democrats]] [[Category:American philanthropists]] [[Category:Founders of schools in the United States]] [[Category:American abolitionists]] [[Category:American Unitarians]] [[Category:American expatriates in France]] [[Category:American expatriates in China]] [[Category:Forbes family|John Murray]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2015}} {{Infobox person | image = | image_size = | name = Krit Ratanarak | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1946|4|19|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Bangkok]], Thailand | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | restingplace = | nationality = Thai | religion = | ethnicity = | residence = [[Bangkok]], Thailand | education = | alma mater = | occupation = Chairman, [[Bangkok Broadcasting & Television Company]] | salary = | networth = [[United States dollar|$]]5.4 billion (January 2015){{cite web|title=Krit Ratanarak|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/krit-ratanarak/|website=Forbes|accessdate=9 January 2015}} | spouse = Srisakul Promphan (div.)
Chaisakhran Hiranyaphruek (div.) | parents = | children = [[Chachchon Ratanarak]] | relatives = | website = }} '''Krit Ratanarak''' ({{th-lang|กฤตย์ รัตนรักษ์}}; {{RTGS|''Krit Rattanarak''}}; born 19 April 1946) is the Chairman of [[Bangkok Broadcasting & Television Company]] (operator of Channel 7) and head of one of Thailand’s leading family business groups. The Ratanarak family have substantial holdings in a number of Thai-based companies including [[Bank of Ayudhya|Krungsri Bank]], Siam City Cement, Allianz Ayudhya, Sri Ayudhya Capital, Matching Studio, Media of Medias and Eastern Star Real Estate as well as holding a majority stake in BBTV. ==Family== Krit Ratanarak was born in 1946 and is the eldest of six children with five sisters, four of whom now live outside Thailand.{{cite news|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qa3715/is_199809/ai_n8814582/pg_33/ |title=Global Finance 600: The world's most powerful financial players |publisher=BNET Find Articles |accessdate=2009-11-09 |year=1998 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101026001643/http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qa3715/is_199809/ai_n8814582/pg_33/ |archivedate=26 October 2010 |df= }} His mother, Sasithorn, still lives in [[Bangkok]]. The Ratanarak family are known to be very private; Forbes call them ‘a very secretive clan’{{cite news|newspaper=Forbes Magazine|date=18 July 1994|pages=162}} and Krit’s son Chachchon has been described as being ‘influential while staying below the radar.{{cite news|newspaper=Business Report Thailand|date=January 2012|pages=43–45}} The Ratanaraks are one of the few remaining ‘old money’ families in Thailand.{{cite news|newspaper=Forbes Magazine|date=18 July 1994|pages=176}} Krit is the son of [[Chuan Ratanarak]], who founded Bank of Ayudhya (known today as Krungsri Bank), Siam City Cement (producer of the Insee Cement brand) and Bangkok Broadcasting and Television Hiscock (1997), p. 254 and was one of Thailand’s last great self-made business Titans.{{cite news|title=BANK OF AYUDHYA CHAIRMAN PASSES AWAY|newspaper=Bangkok Post|date=4 August 1993}} Krit took over the family businesses after the death of his father in 1993. ==Career== Ratanarak is one of the most successful and businessmen in Thailand. He joined [[Bank of Ayudhya]] in 1972 becoming President in 1982 and CEO in 1990. In 1993 he became Chairman and CEO of the bank, Chairman of BBTV, Chairman of Siam City Cement and Chairman of Ayudhya Insurance.{{cite web |url = http://www.nationmultimedia.com/2007/01/05/business/business_30023293.php |title = BAY gears up for new era as Krit steps down |publisher = The Nation |accessdate = 2009-11-09 |last = |first = |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070128082252/http://www.nationmultimedia.com/2007/01/05/business/business_30023293.php |archivedate = 28 January 2007 |df = dmy-all }} In the late 1990s, Ratanarak navigated [[Bank of Ayudhya]] and the other family businesses through the worst of the Asian financial crisis with the result that the Ratanaraks were one of only 8 business groups that had been in Thailand’s top 40 in 1979 to survive in the top rankings in 2009. {{cite web |url= http://www.nationmultimedia.com/2008/03/24/opinion/opinion_30068989.php |title=How Thailand's wealthiest are making serious money |publisher=The Nation |accessdate=2009-11-09 |last= |first= }} In the years after the crisis Ratanarak strengthened the major family businesses by introducing outside capital and international management expertise. Ratanarak recapitalised Siam City Cement in 1998 in the process selling part of the family’s equity to Holderbank (later to become [[Holcim]]). Contemporary newspaper reports wrongly suggested that the sale of equity to Holderbank was used by the family to raise the funds required to recapitalize Bank of Ayudhya. However, as part of the terms of the sale, the full proceeds received by the family from Holderbank – as well as additional funds from the Ratanarak Group - were reinvested in Siam City Cement via a rights issue to recapitalize the business and the capital injected by the family into the bank came instead from contingency reserves.{{cite web|title=Before Nowadays…40 Years of Siam City Cement PCL. Special Interview with Khun Veraphan Teepsuwan|url=http://www.siamcitycement.com/downloads/koobaan/20090922124322_KB22.pdf|website=Siam City Cement Vol. 5, Issue 22|accessdate=2 July 2014|ref=Teepsuwan|pages=20–25|format=Interview|date=6 Nov 2009}} In 2013 the Ratanarak family controlled 47% of the equity in Siam City Cement which had a market value of US $3.2 billion and no significant debt with Holcim holding 27.5% of the shares.{{cite news|last=Srimalee|first=Somluck|title=Ratanaraks returning to former prowess|url=http://www.nationmultimedia.com/business/Ratanaraks-returning-to-former-prowess-30196734.html|accessdate=25 June 2013|newspaper=The Nation|date=25 December 2012}} In 1998, prior to the deal with Holderbank, the family had controlled slightly more than 50% of the company.{{cite news|last=Sherer|first=Paul|title=Swiss Holderbank Buys Stake in Siam City Cement|newspaper=The Asian Wall Street Journal|date=11 August 1998}} While other banks closed or were nationalized, Ratanarak completed a recapitalization of Bank of Ayudhya,{{cite journal|author1=Akira Suehiro|author2=Natenapha Wailerdsak|title=Family Business in Thailand|journal=ASEAN Economic Bulletin|year=2004|volume=21|issue=1}} and the bank continued to improve its performance in the post-crisis aftermath. In 1996 before the crisis the bank had a market value of US $4 billion in 2014 prices{{cite web|title=Thailand Closing Stock Prices|work=Dow Jones Newswire|accessdate=20 August 2013|date=10 April 1996}} and this had risen to US $7 billion in 2014.{{cite web|title=Companies/Securities in Focus|url=http://www.set.or.th/set/companyprofile.do?symbol=BAY&language=en&country=US|website=The Stock Exchange of Thailand|accessdate=2 July 2014|ref=Bay}} The family shareholding in the bank was reduced in 2007 from 35%{{cite news|last=Utumporn|first=Pichayaporn|title=Bank of Ayudhya Share-Issue Plan Pleases Shareholders and Analysts|newspaper=The Asian Wall Street Journal|date=7 May 1996}} to 25% to comply with a reduction in the maximum permitted holding under new banking regulations which came into force in 2008. The reduction in the family’s holding was taken up by GE Capital whom the family brought into the management of the bank in 2007 to install best practice.{{cite news|last=Kanoksilp|first=Jiwamol|title=BAY gears up for new era as Krit steps down|newspaper=The Nation (Thailand)|date=5 January 2007}} In 2013 GE Capital sold their holding to Japan’s MUFJ following losses incurred in the 2008 banking crisis,{{cite news|last=Vallikappen|first=Sanat|title=GE Raises $462 Million From Selling 7.6% of Bank of Ayudhya|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2012-09-26/ge-raises-462-million-from-selling-7-6-of-bank-of-ayudhya-1-.html|newspaper=Bloomberg News|date=8 April 2013|author2=Joyce Koh|author3=Anuchit Nguyen}} and a change in strategy by GE to reduce their exposure to financial services.{{cite news|last=Lex|title=General Electric: the long game|url=http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/3/d95e609c-a073-11e2-88b6-00144feabdc0.html|newspaper=Financial Times|date=8 April 2013}} In 2014 the Ratanarak family controlled 25% of the bank’s equity with the remaining equity held by MUFJ. The Ratanarak Group emerged from the crisis with Ratanarak at the head of one of the top five business families in Thailand, and one of three of Thailand’s most powerful banking families along with the Sophonpanich and [[Lamsam family|Lamsam]] families.{{cite book|last=Gomez|first=Edmund|title=Political business in East Asia|year=2002|publisher=Routledge|location=London|isbn=0-415-27149-5|pages=253–277}} Since 1993, Ratanarak has added property companies Eastern Star and Grand Canal Land and media company Matching Maximise Solution to the family business group. In 1981 Ratanarak became Thailand’s youngest senator at the age of 35, serving for four terms. {{cite news |url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qa3715/is_199809/ai_n8814582/pg_33/ |title=Global Finance 600: The world's most powerful financial players |publisher=BNET Find Articles |accessdate=2009-11-09 |last= |first= |year=1998 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101026001643/http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qa3715/is_199809/ai_n8814582/pg_33/ |archivedate=26 October 2010 |df= }} ===2010s=== According to press reports in March 2012, Ratanarak is working to transform the Rama III area of Bangkok into a major commercial centre.{{cite news|title=Five from Thailand join 'Forbes' billionaires club|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/business/economics/283544/five-from-thailand-join-forbes-billionaires-club|accessdate=23 March 2012|newspaper=Bangkok Post|date=9 March 2012}} According to [[Forbes]] the Ratanarak family’s holdings in the group businesses in January 2015 were estimated to be worth US$5.4 billion, based on publicly known assets and excludes private assets and property. In 2012 the Thai publication ‘Which Family is Richest’ reported the Ratanarak family as having holdings in excess of US$10 billion since 1998 when other assets are included.{{cite book|last=Jaiyen|first=Boonchai|title=Which Family is the Richest|year=2012|isbn=978-616-7363-70-7|pages=37–54}} ==Personal life== Ratanarak is divorced with one son, [[Chachchon Ratanarak|Chachchon]], born in 1972. ==References== {{reflist}} ==Bibliography== *Hiscock, Geoff, ''Asia's wealth club: who's really who in business -- the top 100 billionaires in Asia'', Nicholas Brealey Pub., 1997, {{ISBN|1-85788-162-1}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ratanarak, Krit}} [[Category:1949 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Thai businesspeople]] [[Category:Thai billionaires]] [[Category:Thai people of Chinese descent]] [[Category:People from Chenghai]] [[Category:Members of the Senate of Thailand]]

revision.comment: Reverted 2 edits by [[Special:Contributions/216.109.8.50|216.109.8.50]] ([[User talk:216.109.8.50|talk]]) to last revision by 174.4.26.61. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{Redirect|Long run|other uses|Longrun (disambiguation)}} In [[microeconomics]], the '''long run''' is the conceptual time period in which there are no [[fixed factors of production]], so that there are no constraints preventing changing the output level by changing the [[Capital (economics)|capital stock]] or by entering or leaving an industry. The long run contrasts with the '''short run''', in which some factors are variable and others are fixed, constraining entry or exit from an industry. In [[macroeconomics]], the long run is the period when the general [[price level]], contractual wage rates, and expectations adjust fully to the state of the economy, in contrast to the short run when these variables may not fully adjust.Paul A. Samuelson and [[William Nordhaus|William D. Nordhaus]] (2004). ''[[Economics (textbook)|Economics]]'', 18th ed., [end] Glossary of Terms, "Long run" and "Short run."{{cite book|author1=Arleen J. Hoag|author2=John H. Hoag|title=Introductory Economics|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-2AcaoqC-28C&pg=PA119|year=2006|publisher=World Scientific|isbn=978-981-256-891-5|pages=119+}} ==Long run== In the long run, [[business|firm]]s change production levels in response to (expected) [[economic profit]]s or losses, and the [[land (economics)|land]], [[labour (economics)|labour]], [[capital goods]] and [[entrepreneurship]] vary to reach the minimum level of long-run [[average cost]]. In the simplified case of plant capacity as the only fixed factor, a generic firm can make these changes in the long run: * enter an industry in response to (expected) profits * leave an industry in response to losses * increase its plant in response to profits * decrease its plant in response to losses The long run is associated with the [[Cost curve#Long-run average cost curve (LRAC)|long-run average cost]] (LRAC) curve in [[microeconomic]] models along which a firm would minimize its [[average cost]] (cost per unit) for each respective long-run quantity of output. ''[[Long-run marginal cost]]'' (''LRMC'') is the added cost of providing an additional unit of [[Service (economics)|service]] or [[commodity]] from changing capacity level to reach the lowest cost associated with that extra output. LRMC equalling price is efficient as to [[resource allocation]] in the long run. The concept of ''long-run cost'' is also used in determining whether the long-run expected to induce the firm to remain in the industry or shut down production there. In long-run equilibrium of an industry in which [[perfect competition]] prevails, the LRMC = LRAC at the minimum LRAC and associated output. The shape of the long-run marginal and average costs curves is determined by [[returns to scale]]. The long run is a planning and implementation stage. Melvin & Boyes, 2002. ''Microeconomics'', 5th ed., p. 185. Houghton Mifflin.Boyes, W., 2004. ''The New Managerial Economics'', p. 107. Houghton Mifflin. Here a firm may decide that it needs to produce on a larger scale by building a new plant or adding a production line. The firm may decide that new technology should be incorporated into its production process. The firm thus considers all its long-run production options and selects the optimal combination of inputs and technology for its long-run purposes.Melvin & Boyes, 2002. ''Microeconomics'', 5th ed., p. 185. Houghton Mifflin. The optimal combination of inputs is the least-cost combination of inputs for desired level of output when all inputs are variable. Once the decisions are made and implemented and production begins, the firm is operating in the short run with fixed and variable inputs. Perloff, J, 2008. ''Microeconomics Theory & Applications with Calculus'', p. 230. Pearson . ==Short run== All production in real time occurs in the short run. In the short run, a [[profit maximization|profit-maximizing]] firm will: * increase production if [[marginal cost]] is less than [[marginal revenue]] (added revenue per additional unit of output); * decrease production if [[marginal cost]] is greater than [[marginal revenue]]; * continue producing if [[average variable cost]] is less than [[price]] per unit, even if [[average total cost]] is greater than [[price]]; * shut down if [[average variable cost]] is greater than [[price]] at each level of outputs ==Transition from short run to long run== The transition from the short run to the long run may be done by considering some short-run equilibrium that is also a long-run equilibrium as to [[supply and demand]], then comparing that state against a new short-run and long-run equilibrium state from a change that disturbs equilibrium, say in the sales-tax rate, tracing out the short-run adjustment first, then the long-run adjustment. Each is an example of [[comparative statics]]. [[Alfred Marshall]] (1890) pioneered in comparative-static period analysis.• John K. Whitaker, 2008. "Marshall, Alfred (1842–1924)," Price determination and period analysis, ''The New Palgrave Dictionary of Economics'', 2nd Edition.
   • Alfred Marshall, [1890] 1890. [[Principles of Economics (Marshall)|''Principles of Economics'']], Macmillan. He distinguished between the temporary or market period (with output fixed), the short period, and the long period. "Classic" contemporary graphical and formal treatments include those of [[Jacob Viner]] (1931),Jacob Viner, 1931. "Costs Curves and Supply Curves," ''Zeitschrift für Nationalölkonomie'' (''Journal of Economics''), 3, pp. [http://econfaculty.gmu.edu/wew/syllabi/Econ811JournalArticles/VinerJE.pdf 23-46.] Reprinted in R. B. Emmett, ed. 2002, ''The Chicago Tradition in Economics, 1892-1945'', Routledge, v. 6, pp. [https://books.google.com/books?id=rwhrYnGEYdoC&printsec=find&pg=PA192=onepage&q&f=false#v=onepage&q&f=false 192-] 215. [[John Hicks]] (1939),J.R. Hicks, 1939. ''[[Value and Capital|Value and Capital: An Inquiry into Some Fundamental Principles of Economic Theory]]'', Oxford. and [[Paul Samuelson]] (1947).Paul A. Samuelson, 1947. ''[[Foundations of Economic Analysis]]'', Harvard University Press.The law of diminishing marginal r', 5th ed., p. 185. Prentice-Hall. {{ISBN|0-13-019673-8}} The law is related to a positive slope of the [[Cost curve#Short-run marginal cost curve (SRMC)|short-run marginal-cost curve]].While the law does not directly apply in the long run it is not irrelevant. The long run is the planning phase. A manager deciding which of several plants to build would want to know the shape of the SR cost curves associated with each of these plants. Marginal diminishing returns are related to the shape of the short-run marginal and average cost curves. Thus the law indirectly effects long-run decision making per R. Pindyck & D. Rubinfeld, 2001, ''Microeconomics'', 5th ed., pp. 185-86. Prentice-Hall. ==Macroeconomic usages== The usage of ''long run'' and ''short run'' in [[macroeconomics]] differs somewhat from the above microeconomic usage. [[John Maynard Keynes]] in 1936 emphasized fundamental factors of a market economy that might result in prolonged periods away from [[full employment|full-employment]].Carlo Panico and Fabio Petri, 2008. "long run and short run," Short- and long-period in Keynes, ''[[The New Palgrave Dictionary of Economics]]'', 2nd Edition. [http://www.dictionaryofeconomics.com/article?id=pde2008_L000192&edition=current&q=Long%20run&topicid=&result_number=1 Abstract.]John Maynard Keynes, 1936. ''[[The General Theory of Employment, Interest and Money]]'', pp. 4–5. In later macroeconomic usage, the long run is the period in which the [[price level]] for the overall economy is completely flexible as to shifts in [[aggregate demand]] and [[aggregate supply]]. In addition there is full mobility of labor and capital between [[List of recognized economic sectors|sectors]] of the economy and full [[Capital (economics)|capital]] mobility between nations. In the short run none of these conditions need fully hold. The price level is [[Sticky (economics)|sticky]] or fixed in response to changes in aggregate demand or supply, capital is not fully mobile between sectors, and capital is not fully mobile across countries due to interest rate differences among countries and fixed exchange rates.[[N. Gregory Mankiw]], 2002. ''Macroeconomics'', 5th ed. pp. [https://books.google.com/books?id=B-iNoOEoSnkC&printsec=fin&pg=PA240=false#v=onepage&q&f=false 240,] [https://books.google.com/books?id=B-iNoOEoSnkC&printsec=fin&pg=PR12=false#v=onepage&q&f=false 120], and [https://books.google.com/books?id=B-iNoOEoSnkC&printsec=fin&pg=PA327=false#v=onepage&q&f=false 327–329.] A famous critique of neglecting short-run analysis was by Keynes, who wrote that "In the long run, we are all dead", referring to the long-run proposition of the [[quantity theory of money]], for example, a doubling of the [[money supply]] doubling the [[price level]].J. M. Keynes, 1923. ''A Tract on Monetary Reform'', p. 65. Macmillan. ==See also== * [[Cost curve]] (including long-run and short-run cost curves) ==Footnotes== {{Reflist|2}} ==References== * [[Armen Alchian|Armen, Alchian]], 1959. "Costs and Outputs," in M. Abramovitz, ed., ''The Allocation of Economic Resources'', ch. 2, pp. 23-40. Stanford University Press. ''Journal of Business'', 35(3), pp. [https://web.archive.org/web/20120402183106/http://www.marshall.edu/cber/staff/key/hicksm/10-The_Firms_Cost_Function_-_A_Successful_Reconstruction.pdf 235-255.] * Boyes, W., 2004. ''The New Managerial Economics'', Houghton Mifflin. {{ISBN|0-395-82835-X}} * Melvin & Boyes, 2002. ''Microeconomics'', 5th ed. Houghton Mifflin. * Panico, Carlo, and Fabio Petri, 2008. "long run and short run," ''[[The New Palgrave Dictionary of Economics]]'', 2nd Edition. [http://www.dictionaryofeconomics.com/article?id=pde2008_L000192&edition=current&q=Long%20run&topicid=&result_number=1 Abstract.] * Perloff, J, 2008. ''Microeconomics Theory & Applications with Calculus''. Pearson. {{ISBN|978-0-321-27794-7}} * Pindyck, R., & D. Rubinfeld, 2001. ''Microeconomics'', 5th ed. {{About|the investigative journalist|the economics professor|Michael Hudson (economist)|the Middle East studies scholar|Michael Hudson (political scientist)}}
{{Infobox person | name = Michael Hudson | image = | caption = | birthname = | birth_date = | birth_place = [[Richmond, Virginia]] | age = | death_date = | death_place = | education = [[Washington and Lee University]] | occupation = [[Journalist]] | alias = | gender = | status = | title = | family = | spouse = [[Darcey Steinke]] | relatives = | ethnicity = | networth = | credits = | agent = }}
'''Michael Hudson''' (born 1961) is a Pulitzer-Prize winning American [[Investigative journalism|investigative journalist]]. He is global investigations editor at the Associated Press, where he oversees the work of more than 20 investigative reporters and editors in the U.S. and abroad.
Before joining AP, he worked as a senior editor with the [[International Consortium of Investigative Journalists]] (ICIJ).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.icij.org/journalists/michael-hudson|title= Michael Hudson|publisher=International Consortium of Investigative Journalists|accessdate=2012-07-14}}</ref> At ICIJ, Hudson worked on the organization's Offshore Leaks, China Leaks, Luxembourg Leaks, [[Panama Papers]] and [[Paradise Papers]] investigations of offshore [[money laundering]] and [[tax avoidance]]. He was an editor, reporter and writer on the Panama Papers investigation, which won the 2017 Pulitzer Prize for explanatory reporting. He was project editor, reporter and writer on "Evicted and Abandoned," ICIJ's 2015 investigation of the [[World Bank]]'s human rights and environmental records.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.icij.org/project/world-bank|title=Evicted and Abandoned: The World Bank's Broken Promise to the Poor - International Consortium of Investigative Journalists|publisher=}}</ref>
Hudson previously reported on police, prisons, poverty and politics for The Roanoke (Va.) Times and covered business and finance for the Wall Street Journal and the Center for Public Integrity.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iwatchnews.org/authors/michael-hudson|title=Michael Hudson|publisher=[[Center for Public Integrity]]|accessdate=2012-07-14}}</ref> Hudson's book ''The Monster: How a Gang of Predatory Lenders and Wall Street Bankers Fleeced America – and Spawned a Global Crisis,' was named 2010 Book of the Year by ''[[Baltimore City Paper]]''.<ref name=city/>
==Education== Hudson was born in [[Richmond, Virginia]] and grew up in [[Franklin County, Virginia]].<ref name=interview>{{cite web|url=http://us.macmillan.com/author/michaelwhudson|title= Michael W. Hudson |publisher=[[Macmillan Publishers]]|accessdate=2012-07-14}}</ref> He graduated from [[Washington and Lee University]] in 1985.<ref name=times>{{cite web|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9801E4D6113AF932A15755C0A96F9C8B63|title= Darcey Steinke, Michael Hudson |website=[[The New York Times]]|date=2009-06-21|accessdate=2012-07-14}}</ref><ref name=lee>{{cite web|url=http://www.wlu.edu/x51920.xml|title=Award-winning Journalist Michael Hudson Discusses Mortgage Crisis|publisher=[[Washington and Lee University]]|date=November 2008|accessdate=2012-07-14|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304002557/http://www2.wlu.edu/x51920.xml|archivedate=2016-03-04|df=}}</ref>
===Subprime mortgage reporting=== [[Columbia Journalism Review]] has called Hudson the reporter who "beat the world on subprime abuses"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cjr.org/the_audit/opening_bell_91.php|last=Chittum|first=Ryan|title= Opening Bell: Swiss Mess |publisher=[[Columbia Journalism Review]]|date=2008-07-01|accessdate=2012-07-14}}</ref> and credited him with being ahead of the rest of the media in exposing the fraudulent lending practices that were the driving causes of the mortgage crisis.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cjr.org/feature/hudson.php?page=all|last=Starkman|first=Dean|title= The reporter who saw it coming |publisher=[[Columbia Journalism Review]]|date=May–June 2012|accessdate=2012-07-14}}</ref> Businessjournalism.org has called him the "guru of all things predatory lending."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://businessjournalism.org/2011/09/29/predatory-lending-guru-michael-w-hudsons-tips-for-reporting-with-expertise-part-one/|last=Gammon|first=Rosland|title=Investigative journalist Michael W. Hudson's tips for reporting with expertise|publisher=businessjournalism.org|date=2011-09-29|accessdate=2012-07-14|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130414090952/http://businessjournalism.org/2011/09/29/predatory-lending-guru-michael-w-hudsons-tips-for-reporting-with-expertise-part-one/|archivedate=2013-04-14|df=}}</ref> Hudson began investigating the subprime mortgage industry in the early 1990s.
In February 2005, Hudson and ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' staff writer Scott Reckard broke a story about "boiler room" sales tactics at [[Ameriquest Mortgage]], the flagship company of the nation's largest subprime lending operation and sponsor of the 2005 Super Bowl half-time show.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-ameriquest4feb0405,1,5202756.story|last=Hudson|first=Michael|last2=Reckard|first2=Scott|title= Workers Say Lender Ran 'Boiler Rooms' |website=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=2005-02-04|accessdate=2012-07-14}}</ref> [[Columbia Journalism Review]] called the "boiler room" story and a follow-up piece "[t]wo of the most revealing stories on the culture that overtook the lending industry."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cjr.org/essay/boiler_room.php?page=all|last=Starkman|first=Dean|title= Boiler Room: The business press is missing the crooked heart of the credit crisis|publisher=[[Columbia Journalism Review]]|date=September–October 2008|accessdate=2012-07-14}}</ref> In January 2006, Ameriquest agreed to pay a $325 million predatory lending settlement in 49 states and the District of Columbia.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://oag.ca.gov/news/press-releases/attorney-general-lockyer-announces-325-million-settlement-ameriquest-resolve|title= Attorney General Lockyer Announces $325 Million Settlement with Ameriquest to Resolve National Predatory Lending Case |publisher=[[State of California Department of Justice]]|date=2006-01-23|accessdate=2012-07-14}}</ref>
In June 2008, Ireland's ''[[Sunday Business Post]]'' cited Hudson's 1996 book, ''Merchants of Misery'', for "describ[ing], in great detail, how mortgage-backed securities invented in the 1980s were making a large pool of money available to shady lenders who were making predatory loans to very poor customers at very high rates."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://archives.tcm.ie/businesspost/2008/06/08/story33475.asp|last=Barrington|first=Kathleen|title=Main Street misery moves to the markets|publisher=[[The Sunday Business Post]]|date=2008-06-08|accessdate=2012-07-14}}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
Hudson appeared in the documentary film ''[[Maxed Out: Hard Times, Easy Credit and the Era of Predatory Lenders]]''.<ref name=lee/>
===Reporting on whistleblowers=== At the [[Center for Public Integrity]], Hudson focused on [[whistleblower]] issues and other financial stories. His work included a series of articles, "The Great Mortgage Cover-Up," about the treatment of whistleblowers who reported fraud inside the U.S. mortgage industry.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iwatchnews.org/2011/09/22/6687/countrywide-protected-fraudsters-silencing-whistleblowers-say-former-employees|last=Hudson|first=Michael|title= Countrywide protected fraudsters by silencing whistleblowers, say former employees |publisher=[[Center for Public Integrity]]|date=2011-09-22|accessdate=2012-07-14}}</ref> The series identified 63 former employees at 20 financial institutions who claim they were fired or demoted for reporting fraud or refusing to commit fraud.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iwatchnews.org/2011/11/22/7461/whistleblowers-ignored-punished-lenders-dozens-former-employees-say|last=Hudson|first=Michael|title= Whistleblowers ignored, punished by lenders, dozens of former employees say |publisher=[[Center for Public Integrity]]|date=2011-11-22|accessdate=2012-07-14}}</ref> A follow-up piece focused on the story of General Electric Co.'s foray into subprime in 2004-07, reporting on eight former employees of GE's WMC Mortgage unit who say management brushed them aside when they flagged loans supported by falsified documents, inflated incomes or other [[Sleight of hand|legerdemain]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iwatchnews.org/2012/01/06/7802/fraud-and-folly-untold-story-general-electric-s-subprime-debacle|last=Hudson|first=Michael|title= Fraud and folly: The untold story of General Electric's subprime debacle |publisher=[[Center for Public Integrity]]|date=2012-01-06|accessdate=2012-07-14}}</ref> The first installment in the series was selected to appear in the [[Columbia Journalism Review|Columbia Journalism Review's]] ''Best Business Writing 2012''.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.cjr.org/the_audit/introducing_best_business_writ.php|last=Starkman|first=Dean|title=Introducing Best Business Writing 2012|publisher=[[Columbia Journalism Review]]|date=2012-06-13|accessdate=2012-07-14}}</ref>
===Books=== Hudson edited ''Merchants of Misery: How Corporate America Profits from Poverty''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.anitra.net/books/activist/fea_1febmisery.html|last=Freeman|first=Anitra|title= Merchants of Misery: Legal Scams Make Big Bucks Off Poor |publisher=[[Real Change]]|accessdate=2012-07-14}}</ref> He is also the author of ''The Monster: How a Gang of Predatory Lenders and Wall Street Bankers Fleeced America – and Spawned a Global Crisis'', published in October 2010 by [[St. Martin's Press]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://us.macmillan.com/themonster/MichaelHudson|title= The Monster: How a Gang of Predatory Lenders and Wall Street Bankers Fleeced America--and Spawned a Global Crisis |publisher=[[Macmillan Publishers]]|accessdate=2012-07-14}}</ref> The book focuses on two firms – [[Ameriquest Mortgage]] and [[Lehman Brothers]] – that were key players in the rise and fall of the [[subprime mortgage]] industry. It was named 2010 Book of the Year by ''[[Baltimore City Paper]]''.<ref name=city>{{cite web|url=http://citypaper.com/special/topten/the-year-in-books-1.1073869|title=The Year in Books|publisher=[[Baltimore City Paper]]|date=2010-12-08|accessdate=2012-07-14|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120920060332/http://citypaper.com/special/topten/the-year-in-books-1.1073869|archivedate=2012-09-20|df=}}</ref>
===Awards=== Hudson shared a John Hancock Award<ref name=lee/> for financial reporting and a Sidney Hillman Award for social justice journalism for stories in the [[Institute for Southern Studies#Southern Exposure|Southern Exposure Magazine's]] fall 1993 issue titled "Poverty Inc.," about subprime lenders and other businesses that market to low-income and minority consumers. Those stories were also named as a finalist for a National Magazine Award. Hudson shared a [[George Polk Award]]<ref name=lee/> for magazine reporting and a Harry Chapin Media Award for stories published in Southern Exposure about Citigroup's subprime mortgage lending operations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.southernstudies.org/southern_exposure/2003/07/banking-on-misery.html|last=Hudson|first=Michael|title=Citigroup, Wall Street, and the Fleecing of the South|publisher=[[Institute for Southern Studies]]|date=Summer 2003|accessdate=2012-07-14|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120322224745/http://www.southernstudies.org/southern_exposure/2003/07/banking-on-misery.html|archivedate=2012-03-22|df=}}</ref>
Hudson's work on ''The Great Mortgage Cover-Up'' was recognized with an Excellence in Financial Journalism Award from the New York State Society of Certified Public Accountants as well as two "Best-in-Business" awards from the [[Society of American Business Editors and Writers]].<ref>{{cite news | url=http://sabew.org/2012/03/2012-bib-award-winners/|title=Complete list of winners in SABEW's 17th annual Best in Business Awards|publisher=[[Society of American Business Editors and Writers]]|accessdate=2012-06-10}}</ref>
For his work at ICIJ, he has shared numerous accolades, including a Barlett and Steele Gold Medal, an Investigative Reporters and Editors Award, a Scripps-Howard Award for business/economic reporting, two [[George Polk Awards]], a SPJ/[[Sigma Delta Chi Award]] for online investigative reporting and three [[New York Press Club]] awards for online business reporting. ICIJ's World Bank investigation, which Hudson led as project editor and reporter/writer, won a dozen honors, including an Overseas Press Club Award, a [[National Headliner Award]] and an [[Online News Association]] Award for Innovation in Investigative Reporting (Large Media Category).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://journalists.org/2015/08/11/2015-online-journalism-awards-finalists-announced/|title=2015 Online Journalism Awards finalists announced - Online News Association|website=journalists.org}}</ref>
===Publications and broadcast appearances=== Hudson's writing has appeared in a number of publications, including ''Le Monde'', ''El Pais'', ''The Sydney Morning Herald'', ''[[Forbes]]'',<ref name=lee/> ''[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]'', ''[[The New York Times]]'',<ref name=lee/> ''[[The Washington Post]]'',<ref name=lee/> ''[[AARP: The Magazine]]'', ''[[The Huffington Post]]'',<ref name=lee/> ''[[Washington Monthly]]'' and ''[[National Law Journal]]''. He has appeared on [[C-SPAN]], ''[[NBC Nightly News]]'', and National Public Radio's ''[[Morning Edition]]'', ''[[Talk of the Nation]]'', and ''[[Fresh Air with Terry Gross]]''. Hudson has been interviewed by ''[[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]]''.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.motherjones.com/media/2010/10/michael-w-hudson-monster-foreclosures|last=Kroll|first=Andy|title=Sex, Drugs, and the Subprime Meltdown|publisher=[[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]]|date=2010-10-26|accessdate=2012-06-10}}</ref>
==Criticism== Some business representatives have been critical of Hudson's reporting. Lawyers for Ford Motor Company criticized Hudson's 1990s reporting on Associates Financial Services, the Ford subprime lending subsidiary that was later the subject of a predatory lending settlement with the [[Federal Trade Commission]]. The lawyers called Hudson's book, ''Merchants of Misery'', which included a chapter on Ford and Associates, "impertinent" and "scandalous."<ref>Preface to second printing of Merchants of Misery (Common Courage Press, 1996)</ref> [[IndyMac]] Bank objected<ref name="auto">{{cite news | url= http://www.allbusiness.com/banking-finance/banking-lending-credit-services-mortgage/11582314-1.html|last=Clough|first=Richard|title=IndyMac born and died in Countrywide's shadow|publisher= [[Los Angeles Business Journal]]|date= 2008-07-21|accessdate= 2012-07-14}}</ref> to a June 30, 2008, report that Hudson wrote for the Center for Responsible Lending, ''IndyMac: What Went Wrong?'', which found evidence that the bank had "engaged in unsound and abusive lending during the mortgage boom, routinely making loans without regard to borrowers' ability to repay."<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.responsiblelending.org/mortgage-lending/research-analysis/indymac_what_went_wrong.pdf|last=Hudson|first=Michael|title=IndyMac: What Went Wrong?|publisher= [[Center for Responsible Lending]]|date= 2008-06-30|accessdate= 2012-07-14}}</ref> Shortly before the bank was seized by federal regulators, an IndyMac spokesman dismissed the report as a "hit piece" that "relies on unsubstantiated anecdotal evidence."<ref name="auto"/> The U.S. Department of the Treasury inspector general's office later reported that its investigation indicated IndyMac had done "little, if any, review of borrower qualifications, including income, assets and employment."<ref>{{cite news | url= https://www.scribd.com/doc/13059311/Indymac-Bank-Thrift-Financial-Report|title=Safety and Soundness: Material Loss Review of IndyMac Bank, FSB|publisher= Office of Inspector General, Department of the Treasury|date= 2009-02-26|accessdate= 2012-07-14}}</ref>
==Personal life== Hudson married author [[Darcey Steinke]] in June 2009. It is his second marriage.<ref name=times/>
==References== <!--- See [[Wikipedia:Footnotes]] on how to create references using tags which will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist|2}}
